sub_topic: Applying the Fourier transform to signal processing
message_1: If a signal is given as $f(t) = 2\cos(3\pi t) + 3\sin(5\pi t)$, what will be the Fourier transform of this signal and what will be the frequency spectrum of the resulting signal?
message_2:
To find the Fourier transform of the given signal, we can use the following definition of the continuous-time Fourier transform:

$$F(\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) e^{-j\omega t} dt$$

Given the signal $f(t) = 2\cos(3\pi t) + 3\sin(5\pi t)$, we can rewrite it using Euler's formula:

$$f(t) = 2\frac{e^{j3\pi t} + e^{-j3\pi t}}{2} + 3\frac{e^{j5\pi t} - e^{-j5\pi t}}{2j}$$

Now, we can find the Fourier transform:

$$F(\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \left[2\frac{e^{j3\pi t} + e^{-j3\pi t}}{2} + 3\frac{e^{j5\pi t} - e^{-j5\pi t}}{2j}\right] e^{-j\omega t} dt$$

Separate the integrals:

$$F(\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \left[\frac{e^{j3\pi t} + e^{-j3\pi t}}{2} e^{-j\omega t}\right] dt + \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \left[\frac{3}{2j}(e^{j5\pi t} - e^{-j5\pi t}) e^{-j\omega t}\right] dt$$

Now, we can solve the integrals separately:

$$F_1(\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \left[\frac{e^{j3\pi t} + e^{-j3\pi t}}{2} e^{-j\omega t}\right] dt = \pi\left[\delta(\omega - 3\pi) + \delta(\omega + 3\pi)\right]$$

$$F_2(\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \left[\frac{3}{2j}(e^{j5\pi t} - e^{-j5\pi t}) e^{-j\omega t}\right] dt = \frac{3\pi}{j}\left[\delta(\omega - 5\pi) - \delta(\omega + 5\pi)\right]$$

Now, combine the results:

$$F(\omega) = F_1(\omega) + F_2(\omega) = \pi\left[\delta(\omega - 3\pi) + \delta(\omega + 3\pi)\right] + \frac{3\pi}{j}\left[\delta(\omega - 5\pi) - \delta(\omega + 5\pi)\right]$$

The frequency spectrum of the resulting signal will have impulses at the frequencies corresponding to the Dirac delta functions:

- An impulse at $\omega = \pm 3\pi$ with amplitude $\pi$
- An impulse at $\omega = \pm 5\pi$ with amplitude $\frac{3\pi}{j}$
